Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Acquisition of CDK by Brookfield
Subsubsection Text: As disclosed in “Note 1, Basis of Presentation” to the consolidated audited financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum, CDK and its subsidiaries (excluding the existing non-controlling interest) were acquired on July 6, 2022 by Brookfield and the acquisition-related entities created by Brookfield. All of CDK’s then-outstanding common stock, including outstanding stock-based compensation awards and restricted stock shares issued under CDK’s 2014 Omnibus Award Plan, and over 93% of its then-outstanding long-term debt were tendered for cash totaling $8,312.6 million. The $8,312.6 million acquisition price was funded by $3,413.0 million of cash infused by Brookfield and affiliates and by $4,899.6 million, net of origination costs and discount, from new debt facilities arranged to complete the acquisition. The $8,312.6 million of consideration was allocated to net tangible and intangible assets with a fair value of $3,923.5 million and to goodwill in the amount of $4,389.1 million. 68 ----- CDK elected to apply pushdown accounting with respect to the Acquisition, as permitted by GAAP, whereby the acquisition-date fair values assigned to CDK’s assets acquired and liabilities assumed by the acquirer were pushed down to the financial statements of CDK. Since CDK’s post-Acquisition financial statements reflect a new basis of accounting due to pushdown accounting applied by CDK, CDK’s financial position, results of operations, and cash flows for periods before and after the date of the Acquisition are not comparable. Therefore, in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” CDK’s financial information for periods prior to and including July 5, 2022 are referred to as the predecessor periods (“Predecessor”) and the periods subsequent to and including July 6, 2022 are referred to as the successor periods (“Successor”). In connection with the Acquisition, CDK also changed its annual reporting year end from June 30 to December 31 to align with Brookfield’s annual reporting period. This “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” includes comparative combined financial information, which management believes provides valuable and relevant analyses to fully discuss operating trends and changes. Accordingly, for a comparative discussion and analysis of our operations, cash flows and financial condition in the following discussion, the 179-day Successor period of July 6 to December 31, 2022 has been added to the 5-day Predecessor period of July 1 to July 5, 2022 to present a combined six months ended December 31, 2022 (Combined) that is compared to the six months ended December 31, 2021 (Predecessor). Additionally, the twelve-month period ended June 30, 2022 (Predecessor and formerly “Fiscal 2022”) is compared to the twelve-month period ended June 30, 2021 (Predecessor and formerly “Fiscal 2021”) and the twelve-month period ended June 30, 2021 is also compared to the twelve-month period ended June 30, 2020 (Predecessor and formerly “Fiscal 2020”). Along with other material factors, material effects of pushdown accounting for the Successor periods are identified in the discussion and analysis.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Change in Line-Item Descriptions for Certain Expenses
Subsubsection Text: During the six-month reporting period ended December 31, 2022, we changed certain expense descriptions and classifications on our Consolidated Statement of Operations, Cash Flows, and Balance Sheet. Comparative periods in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” were recast to conform to the current presentation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Sale of the International and Digital Marketing Businesses
Subsubsection Text: On March 1, 2021, CDK completed the sale of the CDK International business (“International Business”) to Francisco Partners. On April 21, 2020, CDK completed the sale of the Digital Marketing Business to Sincro LLC. The International Business and Digital Marketing Business are presented as discontinued operations. For additional information refer to “Note 1, Basis of Presentation” and “Note 4, Discontinued Operations (Predecessor)” to the consolidated audited financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Dispositions of Heavy Equipment and Recreation Businesses
Subsubsection Text: We (i) sold our Heavy Equipment business on May 1, 2023 and (ii) spun out our Recreation business to a direct subsidiary of Central TopCo Inc. on April 30, 2023. These businesses represented an estimated $1.2 billion of net assets comprised mainly of goodwill and intangibles. In connection with the Heavy Equipment business transaction, we received total consideration of $427.3 million in cash, which we distributed as permitted under the First Lien Credit Facility and the indenture governing the Existing First Lien Notes, and a note receivable in principal amount of $58.6 million maturing in 2029. The Heavy Equipment and Recreation businesses have largely operated independently of our Automotive and Heavy Truck businesses and products, with specific sales and operations tailored to their respective industries. These dispositions allow us to focus on our core Automotive and Heavy Truck businesses and continue to invest in areas that will accelerate our growth and create greater value for our customers. The Heavy Equipment and Recreation businesses no longer form part of our results of operations as of May 1, 2023 and April 30, 2023, respectively, and therefore will not be as will be reflected in our consolidated financial statements for the any periods after May 1, 2023 or April 30, 2023, respectively. 69 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Transfer of Credit Services Business
Subsubsection Text: On March 31, 2023, we entered into an agreement that assigned and transferred our dealer contracts to provide credit bureau services to ODE. Under this agreement, ODE is entitled to the right to receive all revenue and unbilled receivables in respect to our Credit Services business and in exchange for enabling ODE to provide credit products to our automotive dealership customer, we receive a commission. As a result of this transaction, we will no longer report revenue for our Credit Services business and will instead report other revenue for the commission we receive.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to bring new solutions to market, research and develop, or acquire the data and technology that enables those solutions is important to our continued success. In addition, our strategy includes the selective pursuit of acquisitions that support or complement our existing technology and solution set, including through our acquisition of Square Root, Inc. (“Square Root”), an Austin-based developer of data curation software for original equipment manufacturers (“OEMs”), on February 1, 2021, our acquisition of Roadster, Inc. (“Roadster”), a Palo Alto, California-based digital sales platform that modernizes the way consumers buy vehicles and the process in which dealers sell them, on June 2, 2021, and our acquisition of Salty Dot, Inc., a privately held automobile insurance technology solution provider, on October 1, 2021. For example, dealers and OEMs are accelerating their adoption of a modern retailing experience for consumers that will allow the option of completing transactions online or in store. Our acquisition of Roadster paired with ELEAD’s automotive CRM software and call center solutions enhances our end-to-end digital retail experience. An inability to invest in the continued development of new solutions for the automotive marketplace, or an inability to acquire, or successfully integrate acquired, new technology or solutions due to a lack of liquidity or resources, could impair our strategic position.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Data Security and Intellectual Property
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends on our ability to maintain the security of our data and intellectual property, as well as our customers’ data. Although we maintain a clear focus on data and system security, and we incur significant costs securing our infrastructure annually in support of that focus, we may experience interruptions of service or potential security issues that may be beyond our control.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Automotive Market Trends and the Macro Economic Environment
Subsubsection Text: U.S. industry new vehicle unit sales were 7.8 million in the first half of 2023 and 14.2 million in 2022, as compared to 15.4 million in 2021, and 14.9 million in 2020 according to the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis. There continues to be a shortage of available new vehicles for sale as compared to historical inventory levels driven largely by disruptions in the manufacturers’ supply chains. Although new vehicle inventory levels for certain manufacturers improved during the last twelve months, the demand for vehicles generally continued to exceed supply throughout the year. This demand and supply imbalance continues to result in higher levels of profitability for available new vehicles. The reduced levels of total new vehicle availability is currently expected to continue into the remainder of 2023, however, there is still significant uncertainty as to the extent to which new vehicle availability will improve, as well as duration and/or degree of the higher levels of profitability being realized during this time. In addition, the decline in new vehicle unit volume could adversely impact the availability of nearly new vehicle inventory. Additionally, worsening economic conditions, including inflationary pressures and rising interest rates, could adversely impact consumer demand for vehicles. We also expect to see the continued consolidation of dealers into larger dealer groups that could further enhance our position as a strategic partner with larger dealer groups. To some extent, our business is impacted by these trends, either directly through a shift in the number of transactions processed by customers of our transactional business, or indirectly through changes in our customers’ spending habits based on their own changes in profitability. Overall, we believe we are well positioned for further growth opportunities and we remain committed to our business strategy of serving our dealer customers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: A number of material trends and/or uncertainties in our marketplace could have either a positive or negative impact on our ability to conduct business, our results of operations, and/or our financial condition. The following is a summary of trends or uncertainties that have the potential to affect our liquidity, capital resources, or results of operations:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: How We Assess our Performance
Subsubsection Title: Adjusted EBITDA, Further Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin
Subsubsection Text: To provide investors with additional information in connection with our results as determined by GAAP, we disclose Adjusted EBITDA, Further Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin as non-GAAP measures which management believes provide useful information to investors. Adjusted EBITDA, Further Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin are not calculated in accordance with GAAP and should not be considered as a substitute for net income or any other operating performance measure calculated in accordance with GAAP, and may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies. We use Adjusted EBITDA, Further Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin as additional measures of the performance of our business. Adjusted EBITDA is defined as earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization less the following: (1) long-term incentive and stock-based compensation; (2) transaction and integration-related costs; (3) business transformation expenses; (4) purchase accounting adjustments; (5) legal and other expenses related to regulatory and competition matters; (6) amortization of equity method investment fair value adjustment; (6) loss (gain) on extinguishment of debt; and (7) costs associated with our business process modernization, workplace optimization programs, officer transition expenses and adjustment for CDK’s share of income or loss in an equity method investment. Further Adjusted EBITDA is defined as Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted for the dispositions of our Heavy Equipment and Recreation businesses. We believe that the presentation of Adjusted EBITDA and Further Adjusted EBITDA is appropriate to provide additional information to investors about certain non-cash items and other items we do not consider indicative of our ongoing operating performance. Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA is defined as Further Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted for margin improvement initiatives and other adjustments calculated in a manner consistent with the terms of the instruments that govern our indebtedness and are not included in Adjusted EBITDA. Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA has not been prepared as pro forma results under applicable regulations. Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA is included to provide additional information to investors about certain adjustments calculated in a manner consistent with the terms of the instruments that govern our indebtedness. We believe Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA provides a meaningful measure of operating profitability because we use it for evaluating our business performance, liquidity and in evaluating potential acquisitions. Adjusted EBITDA Margin is defined as Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue. Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin is defined as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA divided by Adjusted Revenue. 71 ----- See “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Data.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: How We Assess our Performance
Subsubsection Title: Free Cash Flow
Subsubsection Text: To provide investors with additional information in connection with our results as determined by GAAP, we disclose Free Cash Flow as a non-GAAP measure which management believes provide useful information to investors. Free Cash Flow is not calculated in accordance with GAAP and should not be considered as a substitute for operating cash flow, net income or any other operating or performance measure calculated in accordance with GAAP, and may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies. Free Cash Flow is defined as Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditures and capitalized software. We use Free Cash Flow to evaluate our ability to generate cash that can be used for working capital requirements, interest expense, repayment of indebtedness, financing new acquisitions and for continued re-investment in our business. See “Summary— Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Data.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: How We Assess our Performance
Subsubsection Title: Adjusted Revenue and Adjusted Subscription Revenue
Subsubsection Text: To provide investors with additional information in connection with our results as determined by GAAP, we disclose Adjusted Revenue and Adjusted Subscription Revenue as non-GAAP measures which management believes provide useful information to investors. Adjusted Revenue and Adjusted Subscription Revenue are not calculated in accordance with GAAP and should not be considered as a substitute for revenue or any other operating performance measure calculated in accordance with GAAP and may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies. Adjusted Revenue is defined as Revenue adjusted to exclude revenue attributable to the Heavy Equipment and Recreation businesses, as well as the revenue associated with the transfer of our Credit Services business to ODE. Adjusted Subscription Revenue is defined as Subscription Revenue adjusted to exclude subscription revenue attributable to the Heavy Equipment and Recreation businesses, as well as the subscription revenue associated with the transfer of our credit check business to ODE. The latter results in CDK recognizing future revenue aggregated with Credit Services on a net rather than gross basis. We believe Adjusted Revenue and Adjusted Subscription Revenue provide useful information with respect to the performance of our business because it excludes the impact of the Heavy Equipment and Recreation businesses prior to the date of disposition of such businesses, as well as showing the revenues associated with credit checks on a consistent basis for all periods. See “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Data.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: How We Assess our Performance
Subsubsection Text: We use various GAAP and non-GAAP financial metrics to analyze and evaluate the performance of our business and to provide a greater understanding with respect to our results of operations. These include Adjusted EBITDA, Further Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Free Cash Flow, Free Cash Flow Conversion, Adjusted Revenue and Adjusted 70 ----- Subscription Revenue. Adjusted EBITDA, Further Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Free Cash Flow, Free Cash Flow Conversion, Adjusted Revenue and Adjusted Subscription Revenue have important limitations as analytical tools and you should not consider them in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of our financial performance as reported under GAAP and should not be considered as alternatives to net income or any other performance measures derived in accordance with GAAP as measures of operating performance or as alternatives to cash flow from operating activities as measures of our liquidity. Because of these limitations, Adjusted EBITDA, Further Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Free Cash Flow, Free Cash Flow Conversion, Adjusted Revenue and Adjusted Subscription Revenue should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business. We compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our GAAP results and using Adjusted EBITDA, Further Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Free Cash Flow, Free Cash Flow Conversion, Adjusted Revenue and Adjusted Subscription Revenue only for supplemental purposes. For a reconciliation of these metrics to the most directly comparable GAAP measure, see “Summary— Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Data.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Components of Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Revenue
Subsubsection Text: We receive fee-based revenue generally by providing services to customers. We generate revenue from three categories: subscription, transaction and other. _Subscription_ Our subscription category include revenue received for software and technology solutions provided to automotive retailers and OEMs, which includes: - DMSs and layered applications, which may be installed on-site at the customer’s location, or hosted and provided on a SaaS basis, including ongoing maintenance and support; - Interrelated services such as installation, initial training, and data updates; and - Prior to adoption of Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) 842 “Leases” (“ASC 842”), subscription revenue included technology solutions in which hardware was provided on a service basis. This revenue was previously classified as subscription revenue because under lease accounting guidance in effect prior to ASC 842, substitution rights were considered substantive. 72 ----- _Transaction_ Our transaction category includes revenue received from fees per transaction to process credit reports, vehicle registrations, and automotive equity mining. _Other_ Our other category includes revenue received for consulting and professional services, sales of hardware, and other miscellaneous revenue. After the adoption of ASC 842 in fiscal 2020, Other revenue also includes leasing revenue from hardware provided to customers on a service basis, as hardware substitution rights are not considered substantive.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Components of Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Expenses
Subsubsection Text: Expenses generally relate to the cost of providing services to customers. Significant expenses include employee payroll and other labor-related costs, the cost of hosting customer systems, third-party costs for transaction-based solutions and licensed software utilized in our solution offerings, telecommunications, transportation and distribution costs, computer hardware, software, and other general overhead items.

Subsubsection Title: (Loss) Gain on Extinguishment of Debt
Subsubsection Text: In the six months ended December 31, 2022 (Combined), the Company recognized a loss of $13.1 million on the early redemption of certain debt in conjunction with the Acquisition. In the six months ended December 31, 2021 (Predecessor), a gain of $2.1 million on the extinguishment of debt was recognized as a result of the forgiveness of a Paycheck Protection Program loan that was assumed by CDK as part of its acquisition of Roadster, Inc.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Liquidity and Capital Resources
Subsubsection Text: Our primary sources of liquidity are cash flows from operations and bank borrowings. As of March 31, 2023 (Successor), unrestricted cash and cash equivalents were $97.4 million to fund our general working capital needs, total stockholder's equity was $3,367.3 million, and total debt was $4,963.8 million, net of unamortized issuance costs and an original issue discount of $209.4 million. Working capital as of March 31, 2023 (Successor) was $171.0 million, as compared to $127.7 million as of December 31, 2022 (Predecessor). Working capital as presented herein excludes current maturities of long-term debt and finance lease liabilities and net assets held for sale. Our primary cash needs are for working capital, capital expenditures, operating expenses, acquisitions, the repayment of principal and the payment of interest on our indebtedness. Our historical change in net working capital, excluding change in deferred revenue, has not been a material use of cash (averaging approximately $10.0 million use of cash annually). Changes in deferred revenue have historically been a source of cash given the subscription nature of our business. We believe that our current cash and equivalents, along with cash flows from operations and unused availability under the Revolving Facility will be sufficient to fund our current operating requirements over the next twelve months. Our liquidity and our ability to meet our outstanding borrowings and fund our capital and other requirements are also dependent on our future financial performance, which is subject to general economic and market conditions and other factors that are beyond our control. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flow from operations or that future borrowings or equity financings will be available to meet our liquidity needs. If we were unable to generate new contracts with existing and new customers, if the level of contract cancellations increased, or if contract delays lengthen or increase, our cash flow from operations would be materially adversely affected. We anticipate that to the extent we need additional liquidity, it will be funded through the incurrence of additional indebtedness, equity financings or a combination thereof. We cannot assure you that we will be able to obtain this additional liquidity on reasonable terms or at all. Although we have no current plans to do so, if we decide to pursue one or more significant acquisitions or significant internal growth initiatives, we may incur additional debt or sell additional equity to finance such acquisitions or initiatives. For information on our outstanding debt and borrowing capacity, see “Note 14, Debt” to the accompanying audited consolidated financial statements and “Note 10, Debt” to the accompanying unaudited consolidated financial statements. The Company was in compliance with all debt covenants as of March 31, 2023 (Successor).
